August 23, 2015: Fiction
GO SET A WATCHMAN, by Harper Lee. (Harper.) In the mid-1950s, a grown-up
Jean Louise Finch returns home to find that her adored father is not as perfect as
she believed.
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological thriller
set in the environs of London.
ALERT, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown.) Detective
Michael Bennett and the F.B.I.'s Emily Parker must save New York City from a
deadly threat.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World War
II; the winner of the 2015 Pulitzer Prize.
CIRCLING THE SUN, by Paula Mclain. (Ballantine.) A novel by the author of "The
Paris Wife" about Beryl Markham, a horse trainer and aviatrix who was raised in
Kenya.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the
Resistance in Paris.
LUCKIEST GIRL ALIVE, by Jessica Knoll. (Simon & Schuster.) The life of a
successful New York magazine writer is shaken when secrets from her past are
revealed.
WIND/PINBALL, by Haruki Murakami. (Knopf.) Two newly translated short novels
from the beginning of Murakami's career: "Hear the Wind Sing" and "Pinball, 1973."
THE ENGLISH SPY, by Daniel Silva. (Harper.) Gabriel Allon helps British
intelligence track down the killer of a beautiful former member of the royal family.
DRAGONBANE, by Sherrilyn Kenyon. (St. Martin's.) In the 26th Dark-Hunter novel,
ancient enemies battle.
THE MARRIAGE OF OPPOSITES, by Alice Hoffman. (Simon & Schuster.) The
fictionalized life of Rachel Pomié, a 19th-century Jewish woman on the island of St.
Thomas, whose son Camille Pissaro became a leading Impressionist painter.
CODE OF CONDUCT, by Brad Thor. (Emily Bestler/Atria.) The counterterrorism
operative Scot Harvath undertakes a deadly assignment set in motion by a leaked
video.
DEADLY ASSETS, by W. E. B. Griffin and William E. Butterworth IV. (Putnam.) The
Philadelphia homicide detective Matt Payne looks for a pattern in a series of
murders; a Badge of Honor novel.
August 23, 2015
Non-Fiction
PLUNDER AND DECEIT, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions.) The talk-radio
host urges young Americans to resist the statist masterminds who, he says, are
burdening them with debt and inferior education.
BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME, by Ta-Nehisi Coates. (Spiegel & Grau.) A
meditation on race in America as well as a personal story by the national
correspondent of The Atlantic, framed as a letter to his teenage son.
THE WRIGHT BROTHERS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster.) The story
of the bicycle mechanics from Ohio who ushered in the age of flight.
MODERN ROMANCE, by Aziz Ansari with Eric Klinenberg. (Penguin Press.) The
comedian enlists a sociologist to help him understand today’s dating scene.
MY FIGHT/YOUR FIGHT, by Ronda Rousey with Maria Burns Ortiz. (Regan Arts.)
The U.F.C. women's bantamweight champion and Olympic judo medalist
describes her struggles to succeed.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life and how they
can do better.
DEAD WAKE, by Erik Larson. (Crown.) The last voyage of the Lusitania, the
passenger liner sunk by a German torpedo in 1915.
DOWN THE RABBIT HOLE, by Holly Madison. (Dey Street/Morrow.) Life inside
the Playboy Mansion, by a former bunny and girlfriend of Hugh Hefner.
THE ROAD TO CHARACTER, by David Brooks. (Random House.) The Times
columnist extols personal virtues like kindness and honesty in a materialistic age.
SICK IN THE HEAD, by Judd Apatow. (Random House.) Thirty years’ worth of the
filmmaker’s interviews with comedians.
THE OREGON TRAIL, by Rinker Buck. (Simon & Schuster.) The author and his
brother travel 2,000 miles by mule and wagon from Missouri to Oregon.
BARBARIAN DAYS, by William Finnegan. (Penguin Press.) This surfing chronicle
and memoir by a New Yorker writer.
VOICES IN THE OCEAN, by Susan Casey. (Doubleday.) The study of dolphins:
the research on their brains, their cultural significance and the current threats
against them.
ELON MUSK, by Ashlee Vance. (Ecco/HarperCollins.) Musk’s life from his difficult
South African childhood to his involvement in Internet start-ups like SpaceX.
